name: Second Largest Element in a BST
description:
### Task

~~~if:python
Your task is to find the value of the second largest element in a given BST.

Each element of the BST is a `Node` object or `None` and each `Node` has `3` attributes: `value`, `left` and `right`, with their usual meaning. The trees will always contain comparable values of the same kind, i.e all the values will be of same type.

You should raise an error if:

```
a)The tree contains only one node
b)The Tree is empty(Root Node is None)
```
~~~
~~~if:haskell
Your task is to find the value of the second largest element in a given BST.

The BST definition is `Preloaded` for you:

```haskell
data BST a = None | Node a (BST a) (BST a) deriving (Eq,Foldable)
-- instance `Foldable` is not intended to be actually useful
```

Define a function

```haskell
secondLargest :: (Ord a) => BST a -> Maybe a
```

You should return `Nothing` if

* the tree contains only one node
* the tree is empty
~~~
~~~if:javascript
Your task is to find the value of the second largest element in a given BST.

Each element of the BST is a native `Object` ( `{}` ), which may have `3` properties: `value`, `left` and `right`, with their usual meaning. `value`s in the tree will always be of the same type, and you will be able to compare them.

You should return `null` if:

* the tree contains only one `value`
* the tree is empty ( tree contains no `value` )
~~~

### Example

Given this BST

![BinarySearchTree](data:image/png;base64,)

The second largest element is `70`. So your function should return `70`.

### Notes

~~~if:python 
Max elements in a tree in tests: `1,900,011`
~~~
~~~if:javascript
Max elements in a tree in tests: `100,000`
~~~
~~~if:haskell
Max elements in a tree in tests: `100,000`
~~~

BSTs will not contain duplicate elements.

It is possible to solve this problem in `O(1)` space complexity.

Hint: There is no _need_ to inspect the values of the tree, but you are free to do so. Alternatively, you can rely on the properties of a BST.
